item.title: Anti-inflammatory drugs may hold the potential to alleviate Parkinson's disease, study suggests
item.description: Around 15% of Parkinson's disease cases are related to a known genetic background, out of which mutations in the Parkin and PINK1 genes are among the most frequent ones.

media:content.media:description: Anti-inflammatory drugs may hold the potential to alleviate Parkinson's disease, study suggests

item.title: Two well-known neurochemicals found to be involved in sub-second perception, cognition
item.description: In first-of-their-kind observations in the human brain, an international team of researchers has revealed two well-known neurochemicals -; dopamine and serotonin -; are at work at sub-second speeds to shape how people perceive the world and take action based on their perception.

media:content.media:description: Two well-known neurochemicals found to be involved in sub-second perception, cognition

item.title: Dopamine and serotonin play role in perception and decision-making
item.description: Scientists at Wake Forest School of Medicine have recorded real time changes in dopamine and serotonin levels in the human brain that are involved with perception and decision-making.

media:content.media:description: Dopamine and serotonin play role in perception and decision-making

item.title: Gene variations that regulate dopamine levels in the brain may influence mobility of elderly, frail adults
item.description: Variations in a gene that regulates dopamine levels in the brain may influence the mobility of elderly and frail adults, according to new research from the University of Pittsburgh Graduate School of Public Health.

media:content.media:description: Gene variations that regulate dopamine levels in the brain may influence mobility of elderly, frail adults

item.title: Air pollution can cause neurological damage
item.description: Researchers looking at the brainstems of children and young adults exposed lifelong to air pollution in Mexico City have discovered disturbing evidence of harm.

media:content.media:description: Air pollution can cause neurological damage

item.title: NIH awards $3.8 million to predict dementia in patients with Parkinson's disease
item.description: The National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke at the National Institutes of Health has awarded a grant expected to total $3.8 million to Virendra Mishra, Ph.D., associate staff at Cleveland Clinic Lou Ruvo Center for Brain Health, to identify biomarkers - or disease indicators - to predict dementia in patients with Parkinson's disease.

media:content.media:description: NIH awards $3.8 million to predict dementia in patients with Parkinson's disease

item.title: Stud shows possibility for regenerating neurons in the eye and brain
item.description: The death of neurons, whether in the brain or the eye, can result in a number of human neurodegenerative disorders, from blindness to Parkinson's disease. Current treatments for these disorders can only slow the progression of the illness, because once a neuron dies, it cannot be replaced.

media:content.media:description: Stud shows possibility for regenerating neurons in the eye and brain

item.title: Parkinson's disease is an independent risk factor for dying from COVID-19, study suggests
item.description: A new study of approximately 80,000 patients shows that people with Parkinson's disease (PD) have a 30% higher risk of dying from COVID-19 than people without the neurodegenerative condition.

media:content.media:description: Parkinson's disease is an independent risk factor for dying from COVID-19, study suggests

item.title: Researchers develop unique diagnostic tool to detect dystonia from MRI scans
item.description: Researchers at Mass Eye and Ear have developed a unique diagnostic tool that can detect dystonia from MRI scans, the first technology of its kind to provide an objective diagnosis of the disorder.

media:content.media:description: Researchers develop unique diagnostic tool to detect dystonia from MRI scans

item.title: Spinal cord stimulation improves pain and motor symptoms in Parkinson’s disease
item.description: A team of researchers in the United States and Japan reports that spinal cord stimulation (SCS) measurably decreased pain and reduced motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease, both as a singular therapy and as a "salvage therapy" after deep brain stimulation (DBS) therapies were ineffective.

media:content.media:description: Spinal cord stimulation improves pain and motor symptoms in Parkinson’s disease
